content.description: Very positive holds up an interior corner (featuring a crack) and the narrow face to its right. The top is slightly overhanging. Try to only use the narrow face and avoid stepping into the dihedral, for some challenge.
content.location: A little right of the middle on the Squid Wall, there's a ledge that steps down from the top of the boulder. This problem approaches that ledge from the left.

content.description: Easy balancing up to a big undercling, then a slighlty slopey top-out.
content.protection: At least one pad.   Preferably two, but one of them can be half-size.   There is a rock that comes 1 1/2 ft off the ground, that sits 2-3 feet from the base of the problem.   A spotter wouldn't hurt.
content.location: A little right of the middle on the Squid Wall, there's a ledge that steps down from the top of the boulder. This problem approaches that ledge head-on.
The left, tall arete of the Squid Wall (and some of the left face of the boulder). Closer to Bears Den Rd/the stream.

content.description: Start out on small jug on far right side of traverse.
Short little warmup. Starts on left side of arete (sit on the slanted rock on the ground, hands on crimps, left foot on ledge & right foot smeared onto corner) and goes up.
content.location: Rightermost problem on the Squid Wall. On the arete that is closer to New Cross Dr.

content.description: Sit-start with outward pulls, moves on to a crimp and slightly tricky feet. Then, a throw to a finger jam in a partial pocket (like trying to hold the open part of a "C"). You could also try to crimp or undercling it, but it's a pretty solid lock that you can easily get out of if you need to. It's jugs from there.
content.protection: Pad   Watch out for the tree, but you should be alright.
content.location: On the Squid Wall; from the South and looking North, it starts on the first "lip" that sticks out of the wall, towards the bottom.

content.description: The Squid Wall is a giant slab that contains several different problems, ranging from ~8 to ~18 ft. in height. Some of its problems make good warm-ups.
